Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Uncovering Mechanistic Link Between Autophagy and Circadian Clock in Arabidopsis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
During the daytime plants use carbohydrate generated through photosynthesis to support their growth and development. To avoid starving in the night when photosynthesis is not possible, plants store some of the carbohydrate produced in the day as starch reserve for nighttime use. In Arabidopsis plants, 95% of the stored starch is consumed by dawn. Interestingly, the 24-hour circadian clock controls the rate of starch degradation so that the appropriate amount of starch is used by dawn irrespective of the length of the night. The precise molecular processes involved in clock-controlled nighttime starch usage are not understood. Recently, the autophagy (self-eating) process has been implicated in nighttime starch degradation. This project will investigate the inter-relationship between the clock and autophagy using the Arabidopsis plant as the model system. Results from these studies should provide strategies to improve plant productivity by maintaining the appropriate day-night energy balance especially during changes in environmental conditions. Through its broader impacts, project will train a research scientist, a post-doctoral fellow, and an undergraduate student from Biology Undergraduate Scholars Program (BUSP).

Autophagy is a dynamic process during which double membrane-bound vesicles called autophagosomes enclose cytoplasmic materials and target them to the vacuole/lysosome for degradation or recycling. Autophagy (Atg) core proteins are conserved among eukaryotes including Arabidopsis model plant. The ubiquitin-like modifier Atg8 plays a key role in autophagosome biogenesis, cargo recruitment, and autophagosme delivery to the vacuole/lysosome. Arabidopsis Atg8 interaction studies uncovered an intriguing module consisting of Arabidopsis circadian clock components. This project will investigate the possible molecular link between Arabidopsis autophagy and the circadian clock. The project will specifically investigate whether circadian clock regulates autophagy and whether autophagy in turn regulates clock function in Arabidopsis. Understanding the mechanistic link between autophagy and circadian system should provide insights on carbon assimilation and energy homeostasis in plants.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Autophagy is a dynamic process that is conserved across eukaryotes and entails the engulfment of cellular components in double membrane vesicles called autophagosomes. Autophagosomes are then targeted to the vacuole/lysosome for degradation or recycling. It has been well established that recycling of long-lived cellular proteins and organelles by autophagy is an important adaptive response to nutrient deprivation. However, recent studies have revealed that autophagy participates in other diverse biological processes including cellular differentiation and development, tissue homoeostasis, aging, senescence, innate and adaptive immunity, and programmed cell death (PCD).

Ubiquitin-like modifier Atg8 protein plays an important role in autophagosome initiation and biogenesis and recruitment of cargo to autophagosomes. There are nine Atg proteins in the model plant Arabidopsis compared to one in yeast. The biological significance of this Atg8 protein expansion in higher eukaryotes remains elusive.

In this grant, we have identified network of proteins that interact with different Arabidopsis Atg8 proteins using quantitative yeast-two hybrid technology. The identified Atg8 interacting proteins are predicted to play important role in various biological processes. Interestingly, we have found different Atg8 proteins interact with a number of circadian clock components. Our findings indicate a possible functional link between autophagy and circadian clock. Autophagy may be regulated by components of circadian clock and in turn circadian rhythm may be regulated by autophagy.

Broader Impact:

The grant has generated large of amount of data on Atg8 interacting proteins. The analyses of these proteins have generated number of testable hypothesis. Two publications resulted from this grant. The grant has provided training to three post-doctoral fellows and four undergraduate students. 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2018
Modified by: Savithramma P Dinesh-Kumar
